thread.title: James Hardie quarterly revenue edges higher
thread.title_full: James Hardie quarterly revenue edges higher

title: James Hardie quarterly revenue edges higher
text:
James Hardie CEO Louis Gries said "All of our businesses delivered higher volumes, higher average selling prices in local currency and higher EBIT in local currency compared to the prior corresponding period".
James Hardie Industries has trimmed market expectations about its earnings as booming new home building in Australia is offset by an uncertain recovery in the core US market.
The building products maker on Friday reported an adjusted net profit of $US63.5 million ($86.4 million) for the three months ended June 30, up 27 per cent on the same period last year, the group's best quarterly profit result in eight years.
"During the first quarter of fiscal year 2016, all of our businesses delivered higher volumes, higher average selling prices in local currency and higher EBIT [earnings before interest and tax] in local currency compared to the prior corresponding," chief executive Louis Gries said.
Despite the earnings improvement, James Hardie disappointed some analysts with its earnings guidance.
The make of fibre cement trim, siding, boards said it expects to report adjusted net profit of $US240 million to $US270 million for the year ended 31 March 2016, compared with analyst expectations of between $US244 million and $US286 million.
CLSA analyst Andrew Johnston said in a note to clients that the dampening of analysts expectations could be offset by company's strong margin outlook.
James Hardie said its EBIT margins may exceed its already world class target range of between 20 per cent to 25 per cent.
Mr Gries, who is based in the US, said the company is chasing market share in Australia after expanding its production capacity at its Carole Park plant in Queensland.
"As you guys know, your market [Australia] has been on fire," Mr Gries said on an investor call.
"The market is pretty hot. Australia's way forward right now is to grow market share against alternative products."
This week the Housing Industry Association said it expects Australian housing starts will fall from the highest-ever figure of 214,450 in the year to June to 199,400 this year, although this is still well above the historical average of 152,400 new homes a year.
While Australian new home building stays elevated James Hardie is cautious on the sluggish recovery in the US, where the company derives around 80 per cent of its revenue.
"Management cautions that although US housing activity has been improving, market conditions remain somewhat uncertain and some input costs remain volatile," the company said.
Group revenue for the quarter rose 3 per cent to $US62.8 million and adjusted EBIT rose 26 per cent to $US80.7 million.
James Hardie shares were down 1Â¢ to $17.94 at 10:50am AEDT on Friday.
